sections.summary: Component functions: rectifiers, relays, voltage regulators, meters, indicators, integrated circuits, transformers; Resonant circuit; Shielding

questions.text: Which of the following devices or circuits changes an alternating current into a varying direct current signal?
What is a relay?
Which of the following is a reason to use shielded wire?

answers.A: To decrease the resistance of DC power connections
answers.B: To increase the current carrying capability of the wire
answers.C: To prevent coupling of unwanted signals to or from the wire
answers.D: To couple the wire to other signals

questions.text: Which of the following displays an electrical quantity as a numeric value?
What type of circuit controls the amount of voltage from a power supply?
What component changes 120 V AC power to a lower AC voltage for other uses?
Which of the following is commonly used as a visual indicator?
Which of the following is combined with an inductor to make a resonant circuit?
What is the name of a device that combines several semiconductors and other components into one package?
What is the function of component 2 in figure T-1?

answers.A: Give off light when current flows through it
answers.D: Convert electrical energy into radio waves

questions.text: Which of the following is a resonant or tuned circuit?

answers.A: An inductor and a capacitor in series or parallel
answers.C: A resistor circuit used for reducing standing wave ratio
answers.D: A circuit designed to provide high-fidelity audio

sections.summary: Station equipment: receivers, transceivers, transmitter amplifiers, receive amplifiers, transverters; Basic radio circuit concepts and terminology: sensitivity, selectivity, mixers, oscillators, PTT, modulation

questions.text: Which term describes the ability of a receiver to detect the presence of a signal?
What is a transceiver?

answers.A: A device that combines a receiver and transmitter
answers.B: A device for matching feed line impedance to 50 ohms
answers.C: A device for automatically sending and decoding Morse code
answers.D: A device for converting receiver and transmitter frequencies to another band

questions.text: Which of the following is used to convert a signal from one frequency to another?
Which term describes the ability of a receiver to discriminate between multiple signals?
What is the name of a circuit that generates a signal at a specific frequency?
What device converts the RF input and output of a transceiver to another band?
What is the function of a transceiver’s PTT input?

answers.A: Input for a key used to send CW
answers.B: Switches transceiver from receive to transmit when grounded
answers.C: Provides a transmit tuning tone when grounded
answers.D: Input for a preamplifier tuning tone

questions.text: Which of the following describes combining speech with an RF carrier signal?
What is the function of the SSB/CW-FM switch on a VHF power amplifier?

answers.A: Change the mode of the transmitted signal
answers.B: Set the amplifier for proper operation in the selected mode
answers.C: Change the frequency range of the amplifier to operate in the proper segment of the band

questions.text: What device increases the transmitted output power from a transceiver?
Where is an RF preamplifier installed?

answers.B: At the output of the transmitter power amplifier
answers.C: Between the transmitter and the antenna tuner
answers.D: At the output of the receiver audio amplifier

sections.summary: Symptoms, causes, and cures of common transmitter and receiver problems: overload and overdrive, distortion, interference and consumer electronics, RF feedback

questions.text: What can you do if you are told your FM handheld or mobile transceiver is over-deviating?

answers.C: Change to a higher power level
answers.D: Talk farther away from the microphone

questions.text: What would cause a broadcast AM or FM radio to receive an amateur radio transmission unintentionally?

answers.A: The receiver is unable to reject strong signals outside the AM or FM band
answers.B: The microphone gain of the transmitter is turned up too high
answers.C: The audio amplifier of the transmitter is overloaded
answers.D: The deviation of an FM transmitter is set too low

questions.text: Which of the following can cause radio frequency interference?
Which of the following could you use to cure distorted audio caused by RF current on the shield of a microphone cable?
How can fundamental overload of a non-amateur radio or TV receiver by an amateur signal be reduced or eliminated?

answers.A: Block the amateur signal with a filter at the antenna input of the affected receiver
answers.B: Block the interfering signal with a filter on the amateur transmitter
answers.C: Switch the transmitter from FM to SSB
answers.D: Switch the transmitter to a narrow-band mode

questions.text: Which of the following actions should you take if a neighbor tells you that your station’s transmissions are interfering with their radio or TV reception?

answers.A: Make sure that your station is functioning properly and that it does not cause interference to your own radio or television when it is tuned to the same channel
answers.B: Immediately turn off your transmitter and contact the nearest FCC office for assistance
answers.C: Install a harmonic doubler on the output of your transmitter and tune it until the interference is eliminated

questions.text: Which of the following can reduce overload of a VHF transceiver by a nearby commercial FM station?

answers.C: Installing bypass capacitors on the microphone cable

questions.text: What should you do if something in a neighbor’s home is causing harmful interference to your amateur station?

answers.A: Work with your neighbor to identify the offending device
answers.B: Politely inform your neighbor that FCC rules prohibit the use of devices that cause interference
answers.C: Make sure your station meets the standards of good amateur practice

questions.text: What should be the first step to resolve non-fiber optic cable TV interference caused by your amateur radio transmission?

answers.A: Add a low-pass filter to the TV antenna input
answers.B: Add a high-pass filter to the TV antenna input
answers.C: Add a preamplifier to the TV antenna input
answers.D: Be sure all TV feed line coaxial connectors are installed properly

questions.text: What might be a problem if you receive a report that your audio signal through an FM repeater is distorted or unintelligible?

answers.A: Your transmitter is slightly off frequency
answers.C: You are in a bad location

questions.text: What is a symptom of RF feedback in a transmitter or transceiver?

answers.A: Excessive SWR at the antenna connection
answers.B: The transmitter will not stay on the desired frequency
answers.C: Reports of garbled, distorted, or unintelligible voice transmissions
answers.D: Frequent blowing of power supply fuses

sections.summary: Antenna and transmission line measurements and troubleshooting: measuring SWR, effects of high SWR, causes of feed line failures; Basic coaxial cable characteristics; Use of dummy loads when testing

questions.text: What is the primary purpose of a dummy load?

answers.A: To prevent transmitting signals over the air when making tests
answers.B: To prevent over-modulation of a transmitter
answers.C: To improve the efficiency of an antenna
answers.D: To improve the signal-to-noise ratio of a receiver

questions.text: Which of the following is used to determine if an antenna is resonant at the desired operating frequency?
What does a dummy load consist of?

answers.A: A high-gain amplifier and a TR switch
answers.B: A non-inductive resistor mounted on a heat sink
answers.C: A low-voltage power supply and a DC relay
answers.D: A 50-ohm reactance used to terminate a transmission line

questions.text: What reading on an SWR meter indicates a perfect impedance match between the antenna and the feed line?
Why do most solid-state transmitters reduce output power as SWR increases beyond a certain level?

answers.A: To protect the output amplifier transistors
answers.B: To comply with FCC rules on spectral purity
answers.C: Because power supplies cannot supply enough current at high SWR
answers.D: To lower the SWR on the transmission line

questions.text: What does an SWR reading of 4:1 indicate?
What happens to power lost in a feed line?
Which instrument can be used to determine SWR?
Which of the following causes failure of coaxial cables?

answers.C: Rapid fluctuation in transmitter output power
answers.D: Operation at 100% duty cycle for an extended period

questions.text: Why should the outer jacket of coaxial cable be resistant to ultraviolet light?

answers.A: Ultraviolet resistant jackets prevent harmonic radiation
answers.B: Ultraviolet light can increase losses in the cable’s jacket
answers.C: Ultraviolet and RF signals can mix, causing interference
answers.D: Ultraviolet light can damage the jacket and allow water to enter the cable

questions.text: What is a disadvantage of air core coaxial cable when compared to foam or solid dielectric types?

answers.A: It has more loss per foot
answers.B: It cannot be used for VHF or UHF antennas
answers.C: It requires special techniques to prevent moisture in the cable
answers.D: It cannot be used at below freezing temperatures

sections.summary: Using basic test instruments: voltmeter, ammeter, and ohmmeter; Soldering

questions.text: Which instrument would you use to measure electric potential?
How is a voltmeter connected to a component to measure applied voltage?
When configured to measure current, how is a multimeter connected to a component?
Which instrument is used to measure electric current?
Which of the following can damage a multimeter?

answers.A: Attempting to measure resistance using the voltage setting
answers.B: Failing to connect one of the probes to ground
answers.C: Attempting to measure voltage when using the resistance setting
answers.D: Not allowing it to warm up properly

questions.text: Which of the following measurements are made using a multimeter?
Which of the following types of solder should not be used for radio and electronic applications?
What is the characteristic appearance of a cold tin-lead solder joint?
What reading indicates that an ohmmeter is connected across a large, discharged capacitor?

answers.D: Alternating between open and short circuit

questions.text: Which of the following precautions should be taken when measuring in-circuit resistance with an ohmmeter?

answers.A: Ensure that the applied voltages are correct
answers.B: Ensure that the circuit is not powered
answers.C: Ensure that the circuit is grounded
answers.D: Ensure that the circuit is operating at the correct frequency

sections.summary: Basic characteristics of FM and SSB; Bandwidth of various modulation modes: CW, SSB, FM, fast-scan TV; Choice of emission type: selection of USB vs LSB, use of SSB for weak signal work, use of FM for VHF packet and repeaters

questions.text: Which of the following is a form of amplitude modulation?
What type of modulation is commonly used for VHF packet radio transmissions?
Which type of voice mode is often used for long-distance (weak signal) contacts on the VHF and UHF bands?
Which type of modulation is commonly used for VHF and UHF voice repeaters?
Which of the following types of signal has the narrowest bandwidth?
Which sideband is normally used for 10 meter HF, VHF, and UHF single-sideband communications?
What is a characteristic of single sideband (SSB) compared to FM?

answers.A: SSB signals are easier to tune in correctly
answers.B: SSB signals are less susceptible to interference

questions.text: What is the approximate bandwidth of a typical single sideband (SSB) voice signal?
What is the approximate bandwidth of a VHF repeater FM voice signal?
What is the approximate bandwidth of AM fast-scan TV transmissions?
What is the approximate bandwidth required to transmit a CW signal?
Which of the following is a disadvantage of FM compared with single sideband?

answers.B: Only one signal can be received at a time
answers.C: FM signals are harder to tune

sections.summary: Amateur satellite operation: Doppler shift, basic orbits, operating protocols, modulation mode selection, transmitter power considerations, telemetry and telecommand, satellite tracking programs, beacons, uplink and downlink mode definitions, spin fading, definition of “LEO”, setting uplink power

questions.text: What telemetry information is typically transmitted by satellite beacons?

answers.A: The signal strength of received signals
answers.B: Time of day accurate to plus or minus 1/10 second
answers.C: Health and status of the satellite

questions.text: What is the impact of using excessive effective radiated power on a satellite uplink?

answers.A: Possibility of commanding the satellite to an improper mode
answers.D: Possibility of rebooting the satellite control computer

questions.text: Which of the following are provided by satellite tracking programs?

answers.A: Maps showing the real-time position of the satellite track over Earth
answers.B: The time, azimuth, and elevation of the start, maximum altitude, and end of a pass
answers.C: The apparent frequency of the satellite transmission, including effects of Doppler shift

questions.text: What mode of transmission is commonly used by amateur radio satellites?
What is a satellite beacon?

answers.A: The primary transmit antenna on the satellite
answers.B: An indicator light that shows where to point your antenna
answers.C: A reflective surface on the satellite
answers.D: A transmission from a satellite that contains status information

questions.text: Which of the following are inputs to a satellite tracking program?

answers.C: The last observed time of zero Doppler shift

questions.text: What is Doppler shift in reference to satellite communications?

answers.A: A change in the satellite orbit
answers.B: A mode where the satellite receives signals on one band and transmits on another
answers.C: An observed change in signal frequency caused by relative motion between the satellite and Earth station
answers.D: A special digital communications mode for some satellites

questions.text: What is meant by the statement that a satellite is operating in U/V mode?

answers.A: The satellite uplink is in the 15 meter band and the downlink is in the 10 meter band
answers.B: The satellite uplink is in the 70 centimeter band and the downlink is in the 2 meter band
answers.C: The satellite operates using ultraviolet frequencies
answers.D: The satellite frequencies are usually variable

questions.text: What causes spin fading of satellite signals?

answers.A: Circular polarized noise interference radiated from the sun
answers.B: Rotation of the satellite and its antennas
answers.C: Doppler shift of the received signal
answers.D: Interfering signals within the satellite uplink band

questions.text: What is a LEO satellite?

answers.C: A satellite in low energy operation mode
answers.D: A satellite in low earth orbit

questions.text: Who may receive telemetry from a space station?

answers.B: A licensed radio amateur with a transmitter equipped for interrogating the satellite
answers.C: A licensed radio amateur who has been certified by the protocol developer
answers.D: A licensed radio amateur who has registered for an access code from AMSAT

questions.text: Which of the following is a way to determine whether your satellite uplink power is neither too low nor too high?

answers.A: Check your signal strength report in the telemetry data
answers.B: Listen for distortion on your downlink signal
answers.C: Your signal strength on the downlink should be about the same as the beacon

sections.summary: Operating activities: radio direction finding, contests, linking over the internet, exchanging grid locators

questions.text: Which of the following methods is used to locate sources of noise interference or jamming?
Which of these items would be useful for a hidden transmitter hunt?
What operating activity involves contacting as many stations as possible during a specified period?
Which of the following is good procedure when contacting another station in a contest?

answers.A: Sign only the last two letters of your call if there are many other stations calling
answers.B: Contact the station twice to be sure that you are in his log
answers.C: Send only the minimum information needed for proper identification and the contest exchange

questions.text: What is a grid locator?

answers.A: A letter-number designator assigned to a geographic location
answers.B: A letter-number designator assigned to an azimuth and elevation
answers.C: An instrument for neutralizing a final amplifier
answers.D: An instrument for radio direction finding

questions.text: How is over the air access to IRLP nodes accomplished?

answers.A: By obtaining a password that is sent via voice to the node
answers.C: By entering the proper internet password

questions.text: What is Voice Over Internet Protocol (VoIP)?

answers.A: A set of rules specifying how to identify your station when linked over the internet to another station
answers.B: A technique employed to “spot” DX stations via the internet
answers.C: A technique for measuring the modulation quality of a transmitter using remote sites monitored via the internet
answers.D: A method of delivering voice communications over the internet using digital techniques

questions.text: What is the Internet Radio Linking Project (IRLP)?

answers.A: A technique to connect amateur radio systems, such as repeaters, via the internet using Voice Over Internet Protocol (VoIP)
answers.B: A system for providing access to websites via amateur radio
answers.C: A system for informing amateurs in real time of the frequency of active DX stations
answers.D: A technique for measuring signal strength of an amateur transmitter via the internet

questions.text: Which of the following protocols enables an amateur station to transmit through a repeater without using a radio to initiate the transmission?
What is required before using the EchoLink system?

answers.B: Purchase a license to use the EchoLink software
answers.C: Register your call sign and provide proof of license

questions.text: What is an amateur radio station that connects other amateur stations to the internet?

sections.summary: Non-voice and digital communications: image signals and definition of NTSC, CW, packet radio, PSK, APRS, error detection and correction, amateur radio networking, Digital Mobile Radio, WSJT modes, Broadband-Hamnet

questions.text: Which of the following is a digital communications mode?
What is a “talkgroup” on a DMR repeater?

answers.A: A group of operators sharing common interests
answers.B: A way for groups of users to share a channel at different times without hearing other users on the channel
answers.C: A protocol that increases the signal-to-noise ratio when multiple repeaters are linked together
answers.D: A net that meets at a specified time

questions.text: What kind of data can be transmitted by APRS?
What type of transmission is indicated by the term "NTSC?"

answers.A: A Normal Transmission mode in Static Circuit
answers.B: A special mode for satellite uplink
answers.C: An analog fast-scan color TV signal
answers.D: A frame compression scheme for TV signals

questions.text: Which of the following is an application of APRS?

answers.A: Providing real-time tactical digital communications in conjunction with a map showing the locations of stations
answers.B: Showing automatically the number of packets transmitted via PACTOR during a specific time interval
answers.C: Providing voice over internet connection between repeaters
answers.D: Providing information on the number of stations signed into a repeater

questions.text: What does the abbreviation "PSK" mean?
Which of the following describes DMR?

answers.A: A technique for time-multiplexing two digital voice signals on a single 12.5 kHz repeater channel
answers.B: An automatic position tracking mode for FM mobiles communicating through repeaters
answers.C: An automatic computer logging technique for hands-off logging when communicating while operating a vehicle
answers.D: A digital technique for transmitting on two repeater inputs simultaneously for automatic error correction

questions.text: Which of the following is included in packet radio transmissions?

answers.A: A check sum that permits error detection
answers.B: A header that contains the call sign of the station to which the information is being sent
answers.C: Automatic repeat request in case of error

questions.text: What is CW?

answers.B: A digital mode used primarily on 2 meter FM
answers.D: Another name for a Morse code transmission

questions.text: Which of the following operating activities is supported by digital mode software in the WSJT-X software suite?
What is an ARQ transmission system?

answers.A: A special transmission format limited to video signals
answers.B: A system used to encrypt command signals to an amateur radio satellite
answers.C: An error correction method in which the receiving station detects errors and sends a request for retransmission
answers.D: A method of compressing data using autonomous reiterative Q codes prior to final encoding

questions.text: Which of the following best describes an amateur radio mesh network?

answers.A: An amateur-radio based data network using commercial Wi-Fi equipment with modified firmware
answers.B: A wide-bandwidth digital voice mode employing DMR protocols
answers.C: A satellite communications network using modified commercial satellite TV hardware
answers.D: An internet linking protocol used to network repeaters

questions.text: What is FT8?

answers.B: A digital mode capable of low signal-to-noise operation
answers.C: An eight channel multiplex mode for FM repeaters
answers.D: A digital slow-scan TV mode with forward error correction and automatic color compensation

sections.summary: Antennas: vertical and horizontal polarization, concept of antenna gain, definition and types of beam antennas, antenna loading, common portable and mobile antennas, relationships between resonant length and frequency, dipole pattern

questions.text: What is a beam antenna?

answers.A: An antenna built from aluminum I-beams
answers.B: An omnidirectional antenna invented by Clarence Beam
answers.C: An antenna that concentrates signals in one direction
answers.D: An antenna that reverses the phase of received signals

questions.text: Which of the following describes a type of antenna loading?

answers.A: Electrically lengthening by inserting inductors in radiating elements
answers.B: Inserting a resistor in the radiating portion of the antenna to make it resonant
answers.C: Installing a spring in the base of a mobile vertical antenna to make it more flexible
answers.D: Strengthening the radiating elements of a beam antenna to better resist wind damage

questions.text: Which of the following describes a simple dipole oriented parallel to Earth's surface?
What is a disadvantage of the short, flexible antenna supplied with most handheld radio transceivers, compared to a full-sized quarter-wave antenna?

answers.B: It transmits only circularly polarized signals

questions.text: Which of the following increases the resonant frequency of a dipole antenna?

answers.B: Inserting coils in series with radiating wires
answers.D: Adding capacitive loading to the ends of the radiating wires

questions.text: Which of the following types of antenna offers the greatest gain?
What is a disadvantage of using a handheld VHF transceiver with a flexible antenna inside a vehicle?

answers.A: Signal strength is reduced due to the shielding effect of the vehicle
answers.B: The bandwidth of the antenna will decrease, increasing SWR
answers.C: The SWR might decrease, decreasing the signal strength

questions.text: What is the approximate length, in inches, of a quarter-wavelength vertical antenna for 146 MHz?
What is the approximate length, in inches, of a half-wavelength 6 meter dipole antenna?
In which direction does a half-wave dipole antenna radiate the strongest signal?

answers.B: Off the ends of the antenna
answers.C: In the direction of the feed line

questions.text: What is antenna gain?

answers.A: The additional power that is added to the transmitter power
answers.B: The additional power that is required in the antenna when transmitting on a higher frequency
answers.C: The increase in signal strength in a specified direction compared to a reference antenna
answers.D: The increase in impedance on receive or transmit compared to a reference antenna

questions.text: What is an advantage of a 5/8 wavelength whip antenna for VHF or UHF mobile service?

answers.A: It has more gain than a 1/4-wavelength antenna
answers.B: It radiates at a very high angle
answers.C: It eliminates distortion caused by reflected signals
answers.D: It has 10 times the power gain of a 1/4 wavelength whip

sections.summary: Feed lines: types, attenuation vs frequency, selecting; SWR concepts; Antenna tuners (couplers); RF Connectors: selecting, weather protection

questions.text: What is a benefit of low SWR?
What is the most common impedance of coaxial cables used in amateur radio?
Why is coaxial cable the most common feed line for amateur radio antenna systems?

answers.A: It is easy to use and requires few special installation considerations
answers.B: It has less loss than any other type of feed line
answers.C: It can handle more power than any other type of feed line
answers.D: It is less expensive than any other type of feed line

questions.text: What is the major function of an antenna tuner (antenna coupler)?

answers.A: It matches the antenna system impedance to the transceiver's output impedance
answers.B: It helps a receiver automatically tune in weak stations
answers.C: It allows an antenna to be used on both transmit and receive
answers.D: It automatically selects the proper antenna for the frequency band being used

questions.text: What happens as the frequency of a signal in coaxial cable is increased?
Which of the following RF connector types is most suitable for frequencies above 400 MHz?
Which of the following is true of PL-259 type coax connectors?

answers.A: They are preferred for microwave operation
answers.C: They are commonly used at HF and VHF frequencies

questions.text: Which of the following is a source of loss in coaxial feed line?
What can cause erratic changes in SWR?

answers.B: Loose connection in the antenna or feed line
answers.D: Overload from a strong local station

questions.text: What is the electrical difference between RG-58 and RG-213 coaxial cable?

answers.A: There is no significant difference between the two types
answers.C: RG-213 cable has less loss at a given frequency
answers.D: RG-58 cable can handle higher power levels

questions.text: Which of the following types of feed line has the lowest loss at VHF and UHF?
What is standing wave ratio (SWR)?

answers.A: A measure of how well a load is matched to a transmission line
answers.B: The ratio of amplifier power output to input
answers.D: An indication of the quality of your station’s ground connection

sections.summary: Power circuits and hazards: hazardous voltages, fuses and circuit breakers, grounding, electrical code compliance; Lightning protection; Battery safety

questions.text: Which of the following is a safety hazard of a 12-volt storage battery?

answers.A: Touching both terminals with the hands can cause electrical shock
answers.B: Shorting the terminals can cause burns, fire, or an explosion
answers.C: RF emissions from a nearby transmitter can cause the electrolyte to emit poison gas

questions.text: What health hazard is presented by electrical current flowing through the body?

answers.A: It may cause injury by heating tissue
answers.B: It may disrupt the electrical functions of cells
answers.C: It may cause involuntary muscle contractions

questions.text: In the United States, what circuit does black wire insulation indicate in a three-wire 120 V cable?
What is the purpose of a fuse in an electrical circuit?

answers.A: To prevent power supply ripple from damaging a component
answers.B: To remove power in case of overload
answers.C: To limit current to prevent shocks

questions.text: Why should a 5-ampere fuse never be replaced with a 20-ampere fuse?

answers.A: The larger fuse would be likely to blow because it is rated for higher current
answers.B: The power supply ripple would greatly increase
answers.C: Excessive current could cause a fire

questions.text: What is a good way to guard against electrical shock at your station?

answers.A: Use three-wire cords and plugs for all AC powered equipment
answers.B: Connect all AC powered station equipment to a common safety ground
answers.C: Install mechanical interlocks in high-voltage circuits

questions.text: Where should a lightning arrester be installed in a coaxial feed line?

answers.A: At the output connector of a transceiver
answers.C: At the ac power service panel
answers.D: On a grounded panel near where feed lines enter the building

questions.text: Where should a fuse or circuit breaker be installed in a 120V AC power circuit?

answers.A: In series with the hot conductor only
answers.B: In series with the hot and neutral conductors
answers.C: In parallel with the hot conductor only
answers.D: In parallel with the hot and neutral conductors

questions.text: What should be done to all external ground rods or earth connections?

answers.A: Waterproof them with silicone caulk or electrical tape
answers.B: Keep them as far apart as possible
answers.C: Bond them together with heavy wire or conductive strap
answers.D: Tune them for resonance on the lowest frequency of operation

questions.text: What hazard is caused by charging or discharging a battery too quickly?
What hazard exists in a power supply immediately after turning it off?

answers.A: Circulating currents in the dc filter
answers.B: Leakage flux in the power transformer

questions.text: Which of the following precautions should be taken when measuring high voltages with a voltmeter?

answers.A: Ensure that the voltmeter has very low impedance
answers.B: Ensure that the voltmeter and leads are rated for use at the voltages to be measured
answers.C: Ensure that the circuit is grounded through the voltmeter
answers.D: Ensure that the voltmeter is set to the correct frequency

sections.summary: Antenna safety: tower safety and grounding, installing antennas, antenna supports

questions.text: Which of the following is good practice when installing ground wires on a tower for lightning protection?

answers.A: Put a drip loop in the ground connection to prevent water damage to the ground system
answers.B: Make sure all ground wire bends are right angles
answers.C: Ensure that connections are short and direct

questions.text: What is required when climbing an antenna tower?

answers.A: Have sufficient training on safe tower climbing techniques
answers.B: Use appropriate tie-off to the tower at all times
answers.C: Always wear an approved climbing harness

questions.text: Under what circumstances is it safe to climb a tower without a helper or observer?

answers.A: When no electrical work is being performed
answers.B: When no mechanical work is being performed
answers.C: When the work being done is not more than 20 feet above the ground

questions.text: Which of the following is an important safety precaution to observe when putting up an antenna tower?

answers.A: Wear a ground strap connected to your wrist at all times
answers.B: Insulate the base of the tower to avoid lightning strikes
answers.C: Look for and stay clear of any overhead electrical wires

questions.text: What is the purpose of a safety wire through a turnbuckle used to tension guy lines?

answers.A: Secure the guy line if the turnbuckle breaks
answers.B: Prevent loosening of the turnbuckle from vibration
answers.C: Provide a ground path for lightning strikes
answers.D: Provide an ability to measure for proper tensioning

questions.text: What is the minimum safe distance from a power line to allow when installing an antenna?

answers.A: Add the height of the antenna to the height of the power line and multiply by a factor of 1.5
answers.B: The height of the power line above ground
answers.D: Enough so that if the antenna falls, no part of it can come closer than 10 feet to the power wires

questions.text: Which of the following is an important safety rule to remember when using a crank-up tower?

answers.A: This type of tower must never be painted
answers.B: This type of tower must never be grounded
answers.C: This type of tower must not be climbed unless it is retracted, or mechanical safety locking devices have been installed

questions.text: Which is a proper grounding method for a tower?

answers.A: A single four-foot ground rod, driven into the ground no more than 12 inches from the base
answers.B: A ferrite-core RF choke connected between the tower and ground
answers.C: A connection between the tower base and a cold water pipe
answers.D: Separate eight-foot ground rods for each tower leg, bonded to the tower and each other

questions.text: Why should you avoid attaching an antenna to a utility pole?

answers.A: The antenna will not work properly because of induced voltages
answers.B: The 60 Hz radiations from the feed line may increase the SWR
answers.C: The antenna could contact high-voltage power lines

questions.text: Which of the following is true when installing grounding conductors used for lightning protection?

answers.B: Wires must be carefully routed with precise right-angle bends

questions.text: Which of the following establishes grounding requirements for an amateur radio tower or antenna?

sections.summary: RF hazards: radiation exposure, proximity to antennas, recognized safe power levels, radiation types, duty cycle

questions.text: What type of radiation are radio signals?
At which of the following frequencies does maximum permissible exposure have the lowest value?
How does the allowable power density for RF safety change if duty cycle changes from 100 percent to 50 percent?

answers.A: It increases by a factor of 3
answers.C: It increases by a factor of 2
answers.D: There is no adjustment allowed for lower duty cycle

questions.text: What factors affect the RF exposure of people near an amateur station antenna?

answers.A: Frequency and power level of the RF field
answers.B: Distance from the antenna to a person

questions.text: Why do exposure limits vary with frequency?

answers.A: Lower frequency RF fields have more energy than higher frequency fields
answers.B: Lower frequency RF fields do not penetrate the human body
answers.C: Higher frequency RF fields are transient in nature
answers.D: The human body absorbs more RF energy at some frequencies than at others

questions.text: Which of the following is an acceptable method to determine whether your station complies with FCC RF exposure regulations?

answers.A: By calculation based on FCC OET Bulletin 65
answers.B: By calculation based on computer modeling
answers.C: By measurement of field strength using calibrated equipment

questions.text: What hazard is created by touching an antenna during a transmission?
Which of the following actions can reduce exposure to RF radiation?
How can you make sure your station stays in compliance with RF safety regulations?

answers.A: By informing the FCC of any changes made in your station
answers.B: By re-evaluating the station whenever an item in the transmitter or antenna system is changed
answers.C: By making sure your antennas have low SWR

questions.text: Why is duty cycle one of the factors used to determine safe RF radiation exposure levels?

answers.A: It affects the average exposure to radiation
answers.B: It affects the peak exposure to radiation
answers.C: It takes into account the antenna feed line loss
answers.D: It takes into account the thermal effects of the final amplifier

questions.text: What is the definition of duty cycle during the averaging time for RF exposure?

answers.A: The difference between the lowest power output and the highest power output of a transmitter
answers.B: The difference between the PEP and average power output of a transmitter
answers.C: The percentage of time that a transmitter is transmitting
answers.D: The percentage of time that a transmitter is not transmitting

questions.text: How does RF radiation differ from ionizing radiation (radioactivity)?

answers.A: RF radiation does not have sufficient energy to cause chemical changes in cells and damage DNA
answers.B: RF radiation can only be detected with an RF dosimeter
answers.C: RF radiation is limited in range to a few feet

questions.text: Who is responsible for ensuring that no person is exposed to RF energy above the FCC exposure limits?

answers.C: Anyone who is near an antenna
